title: 106_s226
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999". It includes findings and a declaration of policy. The Act "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999" highlights Congress's findings on the negative impact of successive military regimes in Nigeria, praising the current regime led by Gen. Abdusalami Abubakar for progress in liberalizing the political environment. The Act "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999" acknowledges the progress made by the current regime in Nigeria towards liberalizing the political environment. It also mentions the establishment of a timeframe for a transition to civilian rule and efforts to cooperate with the United States in halting drug trafficking. Limited sanctions have been imposed by the international community in response to human rights violations and political repression in Nigeria since 1993. Despite some sanctions being lifted due to recent political liberalization, Nigeria still has decrees in place that suspend constitutional protection of human rights, allow indefinite detention without charge, and revoke civilian court jurisdiction over executive actions. Nigeria is obligated to conduct fair elections as a party to international human rights agreements. Nigeria, as a leading military force in ECOWAS peacekeeping, has played a major role in securing peace in Liberia and Sierra Leone. Despite optimism about progress, recent events in the Niger Delta highlight the critical need for fair elections to express the will of the electors. Recent events in the Niger Delta emphasize the importance of ongoing monitoring to prevent a return to repressive military methods. Congress declares support for political, economic, and legal reforms in Nigeria to ensure respect for human rights and a transition to democratic civilian government. SEC. 3. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The sense of Congress is for the President to coordinate with other countries to promote the rule of law, respect for human rights, and transition to democratic civilian government. Additionally, the President should instruct the US Representative to the UN Human Rights Commission to advocate for Nigeria at the annual meeting. At the annual meeting of the Commission, the United States should condemn human rights abuses in Nigeria and advocate for the renewal of the special rapporteur's mandate. Assistance to promote democracy and civil society in Nigeria. Development Assistance for Nigeria under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 should allocate not less than $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, and $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 to support nongovernmental assistance programs. Development Assistance for Nigeria under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 should allocate funds to nongovernmental organizations promoting democracy, good governance, and the rule of law. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development must ensure that recipients represent a diverse society and aim to advance democracy, human rights, and accountable government in Nigeria. Grants of at least $500,000 per fiscal year for 2000, 2001, and 2002 should be allocated to the United States Agency for International Development to provide grants of up to $25,000 each to support individuals or organizations promoting human rights in Nigeria. In fiscal years 2000, 2001, and 2002, funding of $1,000,000, $1,500,000, and $2,000,000 respectively should be provided to the United States Information Agency for activities in Nigeria promoting democracy, rule of law, and human rights. Congress acknowledges inadequate staff levels at the United States Agency for International Development office in Lagos, Nigeria. Development in Lagos, Nigeria is inadequate. Congress suggests increasing staff at the United States Agency for International Development office in Lagos and considering placement of personnel elsewhere in Nigeria. Prohibition on economic and military assistance to Nigeria, as well as opposition to multilateral assistance for Nigeria. Prohibition on economic assistance to the Government of Nigeria, including funds previously appropriated for such assistance under specific acts. The text chunk prohibits military assistance or arms transfers, excluding certain types of assistance such as disaster relief, refugee assistance, and narcotics control. Prohibition on Military Assistance or Arms Transfers to Nigeria, including funds previously appropriated for military assistance, under chapter 2 of part II of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The text chunk discusses restrictions on military assistance and arms transfers to Nigeria under various Acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Arms Export Control Act. The Secretary of the Treasury must oppose any assistance to the Government of Nigeria from international financial institutions. The international financial institutions mentioned include the African Development Bank, International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, International Development Association, International Finance Corporation, Multilateral Investment Guaranty Agency, and International Monetary Fund. SEC. 6. SENSE OF CONGRESS REGARDING ADMISSION INTO THE UNITED STATES OF CERTAIN NIGERIAN NATIONALS. It is the sense of Congress that unless the President certifies by July 1, 1999, that a democratic transition to civilian rule has occurred in Nigeria, visas should be denied to senior Nigerian government officials and military officers. SEC. 7. WAIVER OF PROHIBITIONS AGAINST NIGERIA IF CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS MET. The President may waive prohibitions in section 5 or 6 for any fiscal year if a determination is made that the Government of Nigeria is not harassing human rights advocates and has implemented a transition program. In July 1998, the Government of Nigeria is expected to respect freedom of speech, assembly, and the media, release imprisoned individuals without due process, provide access for human rights monitors, and repeal laws granting undue powers to the military. The Government of Nigeria has suspended constitutional protection of human rights, allowed indefinite detention without charge, and created special tribunals without due process. Policing in oil-producing communities must be carried out without excessive force or human rights violations. The President can waive the prohibition on the use of force or human rights violations against civilians if it is in the national interests of the United States. Congressional notification is required at least 15 days in advance of any waiver. SEC. 8. REPORT OF CORRUPTION IN NIGERIA. The Secretary of State must submit an annual report on corruption in Nigeria to congressional committees and the public, detailing evidence of corruption by government officials, its impact on government services and U.S. business interests, as well as fraudulent schemes originating in Nigeria. The annual report on corruption in Nigeria includes details on government officials' corruption, its impact on government services, U.S. business interests, and fraudulent schemes from Nigeria. It also covers the impact of corruption on Nigeria's foreign policy. The term "appropriate congressional committees" in the Act refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The provisions of the Act will end on September 30, 2004.
